G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4 and G.L. c. 218, §§ 19, 21 because the events giving rise to this action occurred within Essex County, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19, 21.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4 and G.L. c. 218, §§ 19, 21 because the events giving rise to this action occurred within Essex County, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court under G.L. c. 223, § 1 because the Defendant conducts business in Lynn and the subject property is located within the Court’s territorial jurisdiction.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 15F.proposition: Defendant, as landlord, is responsible for maintaining the common areas of the building, including the hallways and safety equipment such as smoke detectors, pursuant to G.L. c. 186, § 15F and 105 CMR 410.482.

105 CMR 410.482.proposition: Defendant, as landlord, is responsible for maintaining the common areas of the building, including the hallways and safety equipment such as smoke detectors, pursuant to G.L. c. 186, § 15F and 105 CMR 410.482.

Lindsey v. Massios, 372 Mass. 79, 82 (19.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty of reasonable care to maintain the common areas of the building, including safety devices such as smoke detectors, in a safe and operable condition.
Lindsey v. Massios, 372 Mass. 79, 82 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly holds that a landlord owes lawful visitors, including tenants’ guests, a duty of reasonable care in maintaining common passageways under the landlord’s control, and it treats lighting in those areas as part of that duty. While the case specifically discusses lighting in stairway common areas rather than smoke detectors or all safety devices, the reasoning is framed broadly as a general duty of reasonable care to maintain premises (including common areas) in a safe condition, which reasonably extends to safety devices such as smoke detectors.
Lindsey v. Massios, 372 Mass. 79, 82 (19.relevant_excerpt: “Therefore, we no longer follow the common law rule that a landlord owes to his tenants’ visitors the same duty he owes to his tenants concerning the maintenance of common passageways in his control.… The landowner’s duty of reasonable care in maintaining property he controls extends to all lawful visitors on his premises, including the lawful visitors of his tenants.… If Massios violated a statutory duty concerning safe maintenance of common passageways within her control, such a violation is evidence of negligence which the jury may consider.”

G.L. c. 143, \u00a7\u00a7 3\u20137.proposition: Defendant’s statutory duty is further established under G.L. c. 143, §§ 3–7, applicable building and fire safety codes, and 105 CMR 410.482, which require landlords to maintain functional smoke detectors in common areas.

Poitras v. Friendly Home, Inc., 375 Mass.raw_text: Poitras v. Friendly Home, Inc., 375 Mass. 117, 121 (1978)
Poitras v. Friendly Home, Inc., 375 Mass.proposition: Defendant had actual and constructive notice of the defective condition for an extended period before the fire.
Poitras v. Friendly Home, Inc., 375 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a criminal prosecution for possession of untaxed cigarettes and addresses only the validity of a warrantless search based on a clerk’s consent. It does not involve a fire, a defective condition, or any discussion of actual or constructive notice of a defect. Therefore it does not support the proposition that the defendant had actual and constructive notice of a defective condition for an extended period before a fire.
Poitras v. Friendly Home, Inc., 375 Mass.relevant_excerpt: Consent to a search granted by one in control of premises may validate a warrantless search, even where the defendant also has the right to possession and control of those premises. Our opinions in this area have generally involved consent given by one whose authority over the premises was at least as great as that of the objecting defendant… However, it is clear that consent may be given by a third person “who possessed common authority over or other sufficient relationship to the premises or effects sought to be inspected”…

King v. G & M Realty Corp., 373 Mass. 65.raw_text: King v. G & M Realty Corp., 373 Mass. 658, 663 (1977)
King v. G & M Realty Corp., 373 Mass. 65.proposition: Defendant failed to act despite Plaintiff’s repeated reports and complaints, demonstrating a breach of reasonable care.
King v. G & M Realty Corp., 373 Mass. 65.case_name: King v. G & M REALTY CORP.
King v. G & M Realty Corp., 373 Mass. 65.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly notes that the plaintiff ‘complained repeatedly’ over several months about the dangerous stairway and that the landlord ‘had not done anything about it.’ The court affirms a verdict for negligence on the basis of a landlord’s continuing duty of reasonable care to maintain common areas and holds that the negligence question was for the jury. This directly supports the proposition that the defendant’s failure to act in response to repeated complaints can constitute a breach of reasonable care.
King v. G & M Realty Corp., 373 Mass. 65.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiff said that over a period of some months preceding the accident she had complained repeatedly to the defendant, owner of the building, about the condition of the stairs, but it had not done anything about it. … 2. The trial judge was thus correct in charging the jury as he did. There was no basis for allowing the motion for judgment, questions of negligence and contributory negligence being plainly for the jury…”

Jersey v. John Hancock Mut. Life Ins. Co.raw_text: Jersey v. John Hancock Mut. Life Ins. Co., 367 Mass. 491, 495 (1975)
Jersey v. John Hancock Mut. Life Ins. Co.proposition: Defendant’s breach of duty directly and proximately caused Plaintiff’s physical injuries, financial loss, and emotional distress.
Jersey v. John Hancock Mut. Life Ins. Co.support_reasoning: The opinion is a Massachusetts criminal appeal addressing murder and armed robbery convictions, evidentiary issues, jury selection, pretrial publicity, and harmless error. It does not involve a civil claim for physical injuries, financial loss, or emotional distress, nor does it discuss proximate or direct causation of such damages arising from a defendant’s breach of duty. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the stated tort causation proposition.
Jersey v. John Hancock Mut. Life Ins. Co.relevant_excerpt: We agree with the trial judge’s specific conclusion, in his findings of fact on the motion for a new trial, that the evidence of the defendant’s guilt was overwhelming even if only the Commonwealth’s case in chief is considered. The case for applying the harmless error doctrine, if that were necessary, becomes even more persuasive when the extraordinary admissions of the defendant on the witness stand as well as the testimony of the witness Bond are also considered.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes a landlord’s duty to maintain premises in safe condition even for hazards in common areas.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.support_reasoning: The excerpt provided is a concurring opinion focused on abolishing distinctions between licensees and invitees and briefly discussing the treatment of trespassers. It does not address, much less clearly establish, a landlord’s duty to maintain common areas in a safe condition. While Mounsey is a major Massachusetts premises-liability case, nothing in this quoted passage speaks specifically to landlord-tenant common-area duties, so based on the given text it does not support the claimed proposition.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.relevant_excerpt: The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a “licensee” rather than an “invitee,” or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that “trespassers” stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential.

Grady v. Shepard, 212 Mass. 422, 424 (19.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes a landlord’s duty to maintain premises in safe condition even for hazards in common areas.

Hamilton v. Ganias, 417 Mass. 593, 595 (.proposition: Defendant’s inaction constitutes negligence per se under G.L. c. 143 and applicable housing regulations.
Hamilton v. Ganias, 417 Mass. 593, 595 (.support_reasoning: The opinion is a criminal homicide appeal dealing with jury instructions on joint venture, malice, manslaughter, intoxication, voluntariness of statements, and G.L. c. 278, § 33E review. It does not mention G.L. c. 143, housing regulations, premises liability, or negligence per se, nor does it analyze a defendant’s inaction as negligence per se. Therefore it cannot be authority for the proposition that a defendant’s inaction constitutes negligence per se under G.L. c. 143 and housing regulations.
Hamilton v. Ganias, 417 Mass. 593, 595 (.relevant_excerpt: We therefore review the challenged instructions, pursuant to G. L. c. 278, § 33E, to determine whether the instructions created a “substantial likelihood of a miscarriage of justice.” We view the charge to the jury in its entirety “since the adequacy of instructions must be determined in light of their over-all impact on the jury.” … The judge correctly instructed the jury on the elements of joint venture. … The judge’s instruction did not create a substantial likelihood of a miscarriage of justice on the indictment for murder in the first degree…

Glidden v. Maglio, Inc., 430 Mass. 694,.proposition: Defendant's omission foreseeably caused Plaintiff's injuries.
Glidden v. Maglio, Inc., 430 Mass. 694,.support_reasoning: The opinion holds that the plaintiffs failed to prove causation because they could not show why the scaffolding collapsed or link the collapse to any omission by the defendant, including his failure to obtain a building permit. The court explicitly finds that any such causal connection is speculative and insufficient to go to a jury. Thus, the case stands for lack of proof of causation, not that the defendant’s omission foreseeably caused the plaintiffs’ injuries.
Glidden v. Maglio, Inc., 430 Mass. 694,.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiffs failed to proffer any evidence explaining why the scaffold collapsed and therefore cannot establish any causal link between their injuries and the defendant’s breach of any duty to them… The plaintiffs also contend that the defendant’s failure to obtain a building permit…had such an inspection occurred, detection of any defect in the scaffolding might have followed. This conjecture is also insufficient to defeat summary judgment… No rational jury could find in the plaintiffs’ favor on that issue based on the proffered evidence.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u00a7 6B\u20136C.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover all compensatory damages proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence, together with interest under G.L. c. 231, §§ 6B–6C.
